docs.title: Welcome to the Team Wiki 🦾
docs.text: This site contains everything new developers and builders need to get started with our FRC team — including setup guides, robot software documentation, and hardware schematics.

docs.title: 👋 Audience
docs.text:
This documentation is for:

  • New programmers learning FRC Java code
  • Returning team members refreshing their setup
  • Mentors and electrical/mechanical subteams needing software context

docs.title: 🧭 Quick Start
docs.text:
• Getting Started — install tools and clone repos
  • Software — what each repository does and how to use them
  • Hardware — robot schematics and layouts

💡 Tip: Use the search bar at the top of this page to find anything instantly.

docs.title: FAQ ❓
docs.text: Common questions answered here.

docs.title: Team Practices 🤝
docs.text: Coding conventions, review process, and Git workflow.

docs.title: Overview 🚀
docs.text: Welcome to the team! This guide walks you through setting up your development environment and getting your first robot project running.

docs.title: 1️⃣ Install Required Software
docs.text:
You'll need:

  • Java 17+
  • WPILib VS Code (from WPILib Installation Guide)
  • Git for version control
  • Gradle (included with WPILib)

See Installing Tools for step-by-step instructions.

docs.title: 2️⃣ Clone a Repository
docs.text:
Example (2025 Robot):

git clone https://github.com/your-team/frc-robot-2025.git

docs.title: Installing Tools 🧰
docs.text: Before you can start coding for FRC, you’ll need to set up your development environment. Follow the instructions below — you only need to do this once per season or computer.

docs.title: 🧩 1️⃣ Required Software
docs.text: Tool Purpose Download WPILib Core FRC libraries and VS Code extension WPILib Installer Java 17 Language used for robot code Included with WPILib Git Version control system git-scm.com/downloads VS Code (WPILib Edition) IDE preconfigured for FRC Installed by WPILib GradleRIO Build system (bundled with WPILib) Included automatically FRC Driver Station For competition use only (Windows only) NI FRC Game Tools

docs.title: 🪟 Windows Setup
docs.text:
1. Download and run the WPILib Installer (.exe version).
  2. Choose “Install for this user only” to avoid admin issues.
  3. Allow it to install VS Code, Java 17, and GradleRIO.
  4. Verify the installation: bash java -version git --version
  5. Open the WPILib VS Code shortcut created by the installer — it should show the WPILib splash screen.

docs.title: Programming Tutorials 💻
docs.text: Welcome to the programming section! These tutorials will help you understand how our robot code works, and how to contribute new features confidently.

docs.title: 🚦 Command-Based Programming
docs.text:
FRC Java projects use the Command-Based architecture. In this design:

  • Each Subsystem controls one robot mechanism (like drivetrain, shooter, intake)
  • Commands tell those subsystems what to do
  • Triggers/Buttons map operator inputs to commands

docs.title: 📘 Learn More
docs.text:
• WPILib Command-Based Overview
  • What Is Command-Based Programming?
  • Creating Commands and Subsystems

docs.title: 🧠 Java Basics Refresher
docs.text:
If you’re new to programming, start with some quick Java learning:

  • W3Schools Java Tutorial
  • Codecademy Java Track
  • Bro Code YouTube: Java Crash Course

Focus on:

  • Classes and methods
  • Object-oriented concepts (inheritance, encapsulation)
  • Control structures (if, for, while)
  • Using constructors and parameters

docs.title: 🔩 FRC Code Anatomy
docs.text:
A typical robot project (src/main/java/frc/robot/) includes:

  • Robot.java → Main entry point
  • Constants.java → Port numbers and tuning constants
  • subsystems/ → Code for each mechanism (drivetrain, intake, etc.)
  • commands/ → Autonomous and teleop actions
  • RobotContainer.java → Connects inputs to commands

docs.title: Example Command
docs.text:
public class DriveCommand extends CommandBase {
    private final Drivetrain drivetrain;
    private final Joystick joystick;

    public DriveCommand(Drivetrain drivetrain, Joystick joystick) {
        this.drivetrain = drivetrain;
        this.joystick = joystick;
        addRequirements(drivetrain);
    }

    @Override
    public void execute() {
        drivetrain.arcadeDrive(joystick.getY(), joystick.getX());
    }
}

docs.title: Hardware Overview ⚙️
docs.text: Welcome to the hardware documentation for our FRC robot! This section is meant for anyone who wants to understand how the robot is built, how components are connected, and where to find schematics and wiring diagrams.

docs.title: 🧩 What You’ll Find Here
docs.text:
• Electrical Layouts – detailed diagrams of the power distribution, motor controllers, and sensors.
  • CAN IDs & Connections – a list of CAN devices, motor controllers, and their IDs.
  • Robot Schematics – PDFs or images showing wiring, pneumatics, and mechanism layouts.
  • Subteam Notes – important tips from mentors, including common pitfalls and best practices.

docs.title: 🔧 Electrical Overview
docs.text:
The robot’s electrical system is composed of:

  • Power Distribution Panel (PDP) – central hub for power to motors, sensors, and pneumatics.
  • Motor Controllers – Talons, Sparks, or Falcons for driving and actuating mechanisms.
  • Sensors – encoders, limit switches, gyros, and other devices used for feedback.
  • Pneumatics – solenoids, compressors, and cylinders for actuation.

💡 Tip: Always refer to the latest wiring diagram before making changes to the robot.

docs.title: 📦 Mechanical Overview
docs.text:
While software mainly interacts with electrical components, it’s important to understand:

  • The layout of drivetrain motors and gearboxes
  • Placement of mechanisms like arms, shooters, and intake systems
  • Points where sensors are installed

This helps when mapping software to real-world hardware and troubleshooting issues.

docs.title: 🖼️ Schematics and Layouts
docs.text:
All schematics are stored in the hardware/assets folder (or link to your GitHub repository):

Type File Description Electrical Diagram electrical.pdf Full robot wiring diagram CAN Map can_ids.md List of all CAN devices and IDs Mechanism Layout mechanisms.png Physical placement of motors, sensors, and pneumatics

docs.title: ⚠️ Safety Notes
docs.text:
• Always power off the robot before adjusting wiring or replacing components.
  • Double-check all connections against the latest schematics.
  • If unsure, ask a mentor before making changes to prevent damage or injury.

📝 Next Steps: - For detailed information about this year’s robot, see Robot 2025 Hardware

docs.title: Robot 2025 Hardware 🦾
docs.text: Documentation for this year's robot hardware.

docs.title: Software Overview 🧠
docs.text: Welcome to the software section! This area of the wiki is meant to help new developers understand how our robot code is structured, which repositories are used, and how the different components of our robot software interact.

docs.title: 🧩 Overview of Our Repositories
docs.text:
Our robot software is split across multiple repositories, each serving a specific purpose. Understanding the roles of these repos will help you navigate and contribute effectively.

** THIS IS FOR EXAMPLE ONLY. WE WILL NEED TO CLEAN OUR EXISTING REPOS AND PUT THE REMAINING HERE**

Repository Purpose Notes frc-robot-2025 Main robot code for 2025 Uses command-based architecture vision Vision processing and camera tracking Runs on a coprocessor (e.g. Raspberry Pi) pathplanner-config Stores autonomous path data Editable with PathPlanner tool team-wiki This documentation Built with MkDocs Material

💡 Tip: Start by exploring the main frc-robot-2025 repo, then gradually check out the supporting repos.

docs.title: 🔗 How the Software Fits Together
docs.text:
• Main Robot Code: Handles all commands, subsystems, and autonomous routines.
  • Utilities: Provides reusable code like math functions, logging, and configuration helpers.
  • Simulation: Lets you test new features safely without risking hardware.
  • Dashboard: Visualizes telemetry and sensor data for drivers and programmers.

docs.title: ⚙️ Development Setup
docs.text:
Before you start working with the software:

  1. Ensure your development environment is installed (Getting Started).
  2. Clone the main repository and any supporting repos you need.
  3. Follow the project-specific README in each repo for setup instructions.
  4. Test locally using simulation before deploying to the robot.

docs.title: 📝 Next Steps
docs.text:
• Repositories — detailed info about each repository, branches, and workflow
  • Hardware — understand how subsystems map to code
  • Team Practices — coding conventions, Git workflow, and review process

⚠️ Always sync with the latest main branch before making changes to avoid conflicts.

docs.title: Repository Overview 🧩
docs.text:
** THIS IS FOR EXAMPLE ONLY. WE WILL NEED TO CLEAN OUR EXISTING REPOS AND PUT THE REMAINING HERE**

Repository Purpose Notes frc-robot-2025 Main robot code for 2025 Uses command-based architecture vision Vision processing and camera tracking Runs on a coprocessor (e.g. Raspberry Pi) pathplanner-config Stores autonomous path data Editable with PathPlanner tool team-wiki This documentation Built with MkDocs Material

Each repo contains its own README for setup instructions, but this wiki provides team-wide conventions and setup info.
